section.title: Checking In
section.para: On arrival, sign in at the front door. The door to the downstairs stairway will be locked. If the rep or alternate does not have a pass card, an officer will escort him to the security station.

The rep must pick up a badge at the security station outside the EOC room for some events. Once appropriately signed in, enter the EOC, pick up the copy of the position manual in the bookshelf near the door, and go to the Auxcomm desk (first desk to the right when entering the SEOC).

section.title: Contact local jurisdiction
section.para: When the SEOC has been activated, one of the first tasks is to contact the DEC for the affected jurisdiction. In many cases, of course, the DEC may have contacted the SEC in the first place. Even in those cases, contact the DEC so he is aware that the SEOC is activated.
The local ECs affected must also be notified. When speaking with the DEC, decide whether the DEC will notify the ECs or whether they will each get a call from Collins Road.
Be sure to determine, whether through the DEC or directly with the ECs, the communications circuits to be used between the SEOC and the local EOC.

section.title: Liaison with the station
section.para:
One of the rep's primary function is to provide a communications path between the station status and the various agencies.
Apprise the various agencies of the current station status if needed
Communicate the current status of the field situation, as understood by the SEOC, to the station.
Alert the station of any communications needs of the agencies.
If possible, spend some time with the operators prior to the exercise to understand the situation there.
The coordinator will typically communicate with the station via telephone. See Appendix A for numbers.

The coordinator and the station should also agree on a backup communications plan. Typically, the coordinator and a station op should have HTs. A simplex channel should be agreed upon since the station's primary VHF radio will likely be monitoring a repeater involved in, or relaying for, the incident.
Stay in regular touch with the station; be aware of their situation and whether they are in contact with the site. Keep them up to date as to site changes as announced in the SEOC.
If the MARS station is active, be sure to stay abreast of the MARS SitRep and include them in hourly updates. Similarly if REACT, CAP or other services are involved.

section.title: Agency Announcements
section.para: Periodically, the IC or Ops Section Chief will ask for agency updates. Give a brief status of the station for each update. Keep in mind that the agency reps are non-technical, but most realize that we are their backup plan. Give a meaningful status without getting technical. Where possible get information on the program status at the local jurisdiction and, if significant, pass this along to the other agencies as well.
Pay attention to the other agency reports. Should they need us our job will be eased if we at least have some familiarity with their situation.

Consider updating the station with any interesting items from the other agencies. Depending on the drill and players, there may be EOCs on the converse bridge unaware of the situation at the site and in need of update.

section.title: Debrief
section.para: At the end of the exercise, there will be a debrief from all agencies. Prior to this check with the station operators to be sure you are aware of any contact with the site or nearby jurisdictions. Often, the station operators may be invited into the SEOC for the final debrief.
Make a positive, brief presentation when asked. As usual, avoid technical details and focus on capability.
